posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Cullen Gallagher
posts.text: "Jump in and let your enthusiasm be your guide. Just because somebody hasn’t written about a piece of information yet doesn’t mean it isn’t out there—it’s amazing what is just waiting to be discovered."

posts.title: The Irish In Us: A Quick Primer on Irish-American Genealogy Research
posts.text: The reference librarians at the Milstein Division of U.S. History, Local History, and Genealogy regularly field questions from patrons researching Irish relatives. Here's some information to help get you started (or unstuck) doing your own genealogical investigations.

posts.title: Ratification, Discrimination, Adaptation: Researching "Mrs. America"
posts.text: Whether you have watched the show or plan to, Mrs. America serves as a provocative springboard for historical research.

posts.title: Old Time Tours: New York City Guidebooks After the Civil War
posts.text: By the 1890s, NYC guidebooks reflected the self-consciousness of a supercity exposing itself to the world.

posts.title: Old Time Tours: New York City Guidebooks in the Mid-1800s
posts.text: Like the population, NYC guidebooks boomed in the decade preceding the Civil War.

posts.title: Old Time Tours: New York City Guidebooks in the Early Republic
posts.text: A guidebook is the fuel that might power a researcher’s time machine.

posts.title: Forgotten History: The 1858 Quarantine Fires in Staten Island
posts.text: "A group of men wielding hatchets and torches dipped in turpentine split into two groups outside the hospital..."

posts.title: Oscar Night! Researching Local History at the Movies
posts.text: The Milstein Division is a treasure trove for local history researchers.

posts.title: Manhattan Mistabulation: The Story of the 1890 New York City Police Census
posts.text: In 1890, New York City Mayor Hugh Grant believed the recent federal census undercounted the city's population. Local pressure from Tammany Hall and the potential loss of seats in Congress spurred the mayor to deploy the NYPD to conduct its own enumeration of NYC, which results tallied 200,000 more New Yorkers. Some defended the authenticity of the police census - others called it fraud.

posts.title: The New York Public Library's "Ghosts" File
posts.text: The NYC subject clippings collection in the Milstein Division of U.S. History, Local History, and Genealogy includes a small, supernatural file.

posts.title: Genealogy Research on the Front Page
posts.text: Genealogy and local history research is not often headline-making news, but resources in The New York Public Library's Milstein Division are highly relevant to controversies currently flashing big across the news ticker.

posts.title: Genealogy Tips: New York Cops in The City Record
posts.text: Researchers will often ask librarians in the Milstein Division about where to find historical “police records.” If a researcher is looking for an individual who was in law enforcement, The City Record might be a helpful resource.

posts.title: The Titan and the Dictator
posts.text: History is often subject to an arrogant and belabored information literacy.

posts.title: Talking U.S.A. Death Records
posts.text: A death record is a legal statement of fact that provides information for purposes other than the apparent fact that the subject individual is dead.

posts.title: Genealogy Tips: Probate Records in New York
posts.text: In New York City, there are three ways to get started researching probate records.

posts.title: A Brief Passage in U.S. Immigration History
posts.text: In the years after the Revolutionary War, about five thousand immigrants arrived in the U.S. annually; in 2014, one million people obtained lawful permanent residency.

posts.title: The Run for the Roses: An Exciting Two Minutes  of Bluegrass Local History
posts.text: The peak season of professional horse racing breaks from the gate this Saturday at 6:24PM, as 20 thoroughbreds contend nose-to-nose down to the wire for the 142nd Kentucky Derby, at Churchill Downs racetrack in Louisville, Kentucky.

posts.title: City Tabloids, Old Laws, and the Painted Ladies
posts.text: This past month in New York City, political issues have surrounded the Painted Ladies of Times Square like googly-eyed tourists with cameras on selfie sticks. The uproar fittingly abides the municipal brouhaha over the last 100 years that has possessed the behavioral pressure cooker of Times Square. 'Twas ever thus.

posts.title: Sea Blazers and Early Scriveners: The First Guidebooks to New York City
posts.text: The first guidebooks to New York City were written by the navigators, explorers, crewmen, trail-makers, and settlers who sailed west from Europe across the Atlantic Ocean in the 16th and 17th centuries.

posts.title: Lawmen and Badmen: The Tin Star of the Old West
posts.text: In the early American West, the lawman might be a U.S. marshal, appointed by the Attorney General, or he might be a local sheriff elected to office by the townfolk. The distinction often makes no difference in old Western movies, but is an optimum detail in the pursuit of genealogy and local history research in the Milstein Division, where reference librarians must wrangle between the local, county, state, and federal levels in order to rope in relevant resources for patron requests.

posts.title: Jersey Genealogy: A Research Guide Using Local History Collections
posts.text: Perhaps familiar to New Yorkers as a garden state of smokestacks, or surrogate playing field for the Jets and Giants, or otherworld of childhood memory, New Jersey bucks understanding from without and blinkers perspective from within. If your genealogy research leads you to New Jersey, find help with this guide.

posts.title: Class Act: Researching New York City Schools with Local History Collections
posts.text: The history of education in New York City is fraught with strikes, moral stewardship, ethnic discrimination, caritas, religious debate, political bias, Fame, and Welcome Back, Kotter. This guide will serve as a springboard for researching primary and secondary school history at NYPL and elsewhere.
